fields.Transcription:
Ta칤ti, Areitoyaya diri. Da-borinkenoria-k치 *meki dakamadabib치 hi ap칲la techeta marohube. Ico침e, dak칤a dabah칲daguaf치 h'mun lubuku abaraga d'ro-ap칲la 치dianbe-banawarati-oria. Asacapa, dakamada-rotab치 adianbe, ocamak치 adianbe, ahiyank치 adianbe... 츼dianbe-banawararakunoti waboimugaruk치 d'mun. Den칠ganum tohobe-boadianbe'mun kena coa칤tida. Tuei (pasa)k치 tuei d'nukuchuron m'rotak치 tohobe 치dianbe. Tubusieinde marikotan-banoadianbe kei Espa침ol, Chino, kena torabe. Ziua tuei marota-dak치nu. Daroda tohobe (pero) daroda 치dianbe-banawararakunoti saboimugurak치 d'mun. Pero, hurocok치, mabiamra-치diabe-ap칲la. D'nukuchuron par칩de biamakay... Han...

Hah칫-hu ocamabo-ap칲la! H'akamada ta칤guey!
fields.Translation: English: Hello, my name is Areitoyaya. I am from Puerto Rico but Ii have been living here for many years now. Today, I will be telling y'all the conflicting story behind my love for Native American languages. Since forever, I have loved languages, listening to languages, speaking languages... Native American languages are the most beautiful to me. I look at those long words and I get excited. What happens is that my mother does not like those languages. She wants me to learn popular languages like Spanish, Chinese, and etc. It is not that I don췂t like these. I love them but I love Native American languages which are more beautiful in my opinion. But, you know, not everybody has a love for languages. My mother has stopped me multiple times... Yeah... Thank you for watching! Have a good day!
fields.Video Description: This video was recorded in East Hartford, Connecticut in the United States and features Areitoyaya Tunami who moved there from Puerto Rico. The video contains two languages: Spanish, which is spoken in Spain by 38,400,000 people but internationally 414,170,030 speakers and belongs to the Indo-European language family; and Taino which has no known L1 speakers but is being revived by a small population of L2 speakers, belonging to the Arawakan family. Prior to contact with Spanish explorers, Taino was the principal language spoken throughout the Caribbean. As such, it became the first language of the New World encountered by Europeans and therefore was responsible for many words borrowed into European languages. Taino is thought to have died out within a century of Spanish contact, though it may have continued to be spoken by scattered communities until the 19th century. Among the hundreds of words adopted into Spanish and English for unfamiliar plants, animals, and cultural concepts are 'barbakoa' (barbecue), 'hamaka' (hammock), 'iwana' (iguana), and 'tabaka' (tobacco).
italki call to action: Get a free Spanish lesson with italki: http://promos.italki.com/wikitongues_spa
Demographics: 38,400,000 in Spain (ELDIA 2012). Population total all countries: 414,170,030. L2 users: 7,490,000 in Spain (ELDIA 2006).
No known L1 speakers, but emerging L2 speakers.
YouTube License Statement: This video is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International license. To download a copy, please contact hello@wikitongues.org.
fields.Geneaology: "[ Indo-European, Italic, Romance, Italo-Western, Western, Gallo-Iberian, Ibero-Romance, West Iberian, Castilian ]; [ Maipurean, Northern, Maritime, Ta-Maipurean ]"
